text:
Thanks to social distancing, more and more of us are spending a lot of time at home. And that probably means hours spent in front of the TV. But prolonged sitting (and eventual slouching) will likely lead to stiffness and pain of the neck, upper back and lower back.

How do you minimise the pain? Don't forget to move around every 20 to 30 minutes. Neck, arm and leg movements,Â hand squeezes, marching on the spot and mini squats all help too, if you want to be more active.

Medical experts offer more tips on each particular position you see here, check out the story on CNA Lifestyle, link in bio. #socialdistancing #TV #bingewatch #Netflix #backpain #healthtips (Art: Jasper Loh)

text:
In the age of safe distancing and belt tightening, F&B players in Singapore say the industry is hanging by a thread.

The urgent need for support from landlords is a sentiment many restaurant owners share. â€œThere is so much rental pressure on restaurants where the operating cash flow is just two months out. If restaurants and retailers donâ€™t get help from landlords, we cannot survive. (The landlords) have made so much money from us tenants over the last few years and now is the time they really have to step up to help us,â€ said Cynthia Chua of Spa Esprit Group, which includes establishments like Tiong Bahru Bakery.

Substantial rentals are not the only challenge facing Singaporeâ€™s restaurants today. â€œThereâ€™s a lot of uncertainty as to when produce is coming in. Right now, we can get fish locally or from Malaysia, but with meat (mostly from Australia), the worry is what will happen when stocks here run outâ€ said Cheek and Cloudstreet chef-owner Rishi Naleendra.

But the greatest challenge is the lack of traffic. Relishâ€™s Willin Low said: â€œIf people stop coming out, then thereâ€™s no point in keeping a restaurant open.â€ Read the story on CNA Lifestyle, link in bio. #Singapore #food #restaurant #F&B #coronavirus #COVID19 #safedistancing #socialdistancing (Photo: Instagram/Tiong Bahru Bakery)

text:
Singaporeâ€™s safe distancing robodog SPOT somehow made it to The Late Show With Stephen Colbert â€“ and the TV show host pointed out what every Netflix bingers have been thinking all along.

It looks like that creepy robodog in that Black Mirror episode. Except that â€œthis oneâ€™s a jaunty yellow,â€ he joked.

But Colbert said he preferred his dog to be â€œcuter, cuddlier and less dystopianâ€ and suggested an alternative: The Bennybot 9000. Which is basically his pet dog Benny, who is â€œready to be deployed in public parks to spread his message of safety â€“ and steal your shoes and bite your thighs.â€ Read more on CNA Lifestyle, link in bio. #StephenColbert #robodog #Singapore #safedistancing #socialdistancing #Netflix #BlackMirror #Benny #pet #dog #dogsofInstagram (Photos: YouTube/The Late Show With Stephen Colbert)
